mechanism_of_action: Paracetamol selectively inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX-2) more than COX-1 in the central nervous system, reducing prostaglandin synthesis and thereby mediating analgesic and antipyretic effects. It exhibits weak peripheral anti-inflammatory activity compared to NSAIDs. The exact central mechanism may involve additional pathways such as serotoninergic and cannabinoid systems.

pharmacokinetics.absorption: Paracetamol is rapidly and nearly completely absorbed from the small intestine after oral administration, with bioavailability of 70-90%. Peak plasma concentrations are achieved within 0.5-2 hours post-dose. Food, particularly high-fat meals, may delay absorption by 0.5-1 hour without significantly altering extent.
pharmacokinetics.metabolism: Primarily hepatic metabolism occurs via phase II conjugation: 50-60% to paracetamol-glucuronide, 25-35% to paracetamol-sulfate, and 5-10% via CYP2E1 (minor contributions from CYP1A2 and CYP3A4) to the reactive intermediate N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI). NAPQI is detoxified by glutathione under normal conditions. In overdose, glutathione depletion leads to NAPQI accumulation and hepatotoxicity.
pharmacokinetics.elimination: Elimination is predominantly renal, with 90-100% of dose excreted as metabolites in urine within 24 hours; less than 5% is excreted unchanged. Total body clearance is 350-500 mL/min in adults. Half-life prolongation occurs in renal impairment due to metabolite accumulation.
pharmacokinetics.half_life: 1.5-3 hours in healthy adults; 3-8 hours in hepatic impairment; up to 10-15 hours in neonates or severe overdose.

approved_indications: Symptomatic relief of common cold and influenza
clinical_use.standard_dosing: Adults and adolescents >12 years: 500-1000 mg orally every 4-6 hours as needed, maximum 4000 mg/day. Children 1 month-12 years: 10-15 mg/kg/dose every 4-6 hours, maximum 75 mg/kg/day or 4000 mg/day. IV dosing: 1000 mg every 6 hours, max 4000 mg/day.

dose_adjustments.Hepatic impairment (moderate-severe): Maximum 2000 mg/day or avoid; consult hepatologist.
dose_adjustments.Elderly (>65 years): Start at 500 mg/dose; maximum 3000 mg/day due to reduced clearance.

contraindications.Hypersensitivity to paracetamol or excip: Risk of anaphylaxis or severe skin reactions.

contraindications.Severe active hepatic disease (e.g., Chi: Exacerbates hepatotoxicity due to impaired detoxification.

contraindications.Severe renal impairment (CrCl <10 mL/min: Risk of metabolite accumulation; not established safe.

black_box_warnings: Severe liver injury may occur with therapeutic doses (>4000 mg/day) or overdose; acute liver failure can lead to transplantation or death.
Do not exceed recommended dose; multiple products may contain paracetamol leading to inadvertent overdose.

drug_interactions.mechanism: Paracetamol may inhibit warfarin metabolism (CYP2C9) or displace from protein binding.
drug_interactions.management: Monitor INR frequently (weekly initially); consider alternative analgesic if chronic use.

drug_interactions.mechanism: Probenecid inhibits glucuronidation and renal excretion of paracetamol.
drug_interactions.management: Reduce paracetamol dose by 50%; monitor for toxicity.

drug_interactions.mechanism: Induction of CYP2E1 increases NAPQI production; glutathione depletion.
drug_interactions.clinical_effect: Enhanced hepatotoxicity risk even at therapeutic doses.
drug_interactions.management: Avoid concurrent use or limit paracetamol to 2 g/day; counsel on abstinence.

drug_interactions.mechanism: Induction of CYP2E1 increases NAPQI formation.
drug_interactions.management: Monitor LFTs; use lowest effective dose.

food_interactions.mechanism: Delayed gastric emptying reduces absorption rate.
food_interactions.clinical_effect: Delayed time to peak concentration (Tmax increased by 0.5-1 hour); no change in AUC.
food_interactions.management: No dose adjustment; administer without regard to meals.

food_interactions.mechanism: Acute alcohol inhibits CYP2E1, but chronic induces it; variable glutathione effects.
food_interactions.management: Separate by >4 hours if possible; avoid in chronic users.

environmental_considerations: Store below 25°C (77°F), protected from light and moisture to maintain stability.
Avoid freezing IV formulations; discard if discolored or particulate.
Proper disposal of unused medication via take-back programs to prevent aquatic contamination by metabolites.

what_to_do.action: Limit daily dose to 4000 mg in adults without risk factors.
what_to_do.rationale: Reduces risk of hepatotoxicity based on pharmacokinetic data and overdose epidemiology.
what_to_do.implementation: Educate on total intake from all sources (e.g., combination products).

what_to_do.action: Administer antidote N-acetylcysteine (NAC) within 8 hours of overdose.
what_to_do.rationale: Replenishes glutathione to detoxify NAPQI; Rumack-Matthew nomogram guides need.
what_to_do.implementation: IV NAC 150 mg/kg over 1 hour, then 50 mg/kg over 4 hours, then 100 mg/kg over 16 hours.
what_to_do.expected_outcome: Hepatotoxicity prevention if initiated early (>90% efficacy).
what_to_do.monitoring: Serum paracetamol levels at 4 hours post-ingestion; LFTs.

what_to_do.action: Screen for chronic alcohol use before chronic therapy.
what_to_do.rationale: CYP2E1 induction increases NAPQI; limited evidence supports dose cap.
what_to_do.implementation: AUDIT-C questionnaire; cap at 2000 mg/day if positive.

what_not_to_do.action: Do not combine multiple paracetamol-containing products without dose calculation.
what_not_to_do.risks: Inadvertent overdose leading to acute liver failure (40% of US cases).
what_not_to_do.safer_alternatives: Use single-ingredient products; opt for ibuprofen if appropriate.

what_not_to_do.action: Do not use long-term (>14 days) without LFT monitoring.
what_not_to_do.safer_alternatives: Alternate with NSAIDs or opioid adjuncts under supervision.

what_not_to_do.action: Do not administer to patients with G6PD deficiency routinely.
what_not_to_do.risks: Limited evidence of hemolytic anemia (case reports).

debunked_claims.claim: Paracetamol is completely safe with no risk of liver damage at any dose.
debunked_claims.reason_debunked: Therapeutic misadventure causes 50% of acute liver failure cases.
debunked_claims.evidence: FDA labeling, Rumack nomogram trials, AASLD guidelines.

debunked_claims.claim: Paracetamol cures the common cold or flu.
debunked_claims.reason_debunked: Symptomatic relief only; no antiviral activity.
debunked_claims.evidence: Cochrane reviews show no reduction in duration.

debunked_claims.reason_debunked: No prophylactic efficacy; increases hepatotoxicity with alcohol.
debunked_claims.evidence: Small trials show no benefit over placebo.

requirements: Liver function tests (ALT/AST) at baseline and every 2-4 weeks for chronic use (>2 g/day or >7 days).
Serum paracetamol concentration 4 hours post-overdose using Rumack-Matthew nomogram.
INR and renal function in patients on warfarin or with CrCl <50 mL/min.
Signs/symptoms of hypersensitivity (rash, urticaria) with first doses.

warning_signs.Jaundice or dark urine: Hepatotoxicity; discontinue immediately, measure LFTs, consider NAC.

warning_signs.Right upper quadrant pain or nausea/vomi: Early liver injury; urgent LFTs and paracetamol level.

warning_signs.Rash or mucosal involvement: Hypersensitivity reaction; stop drug, supportive care.
